description: From Middle English pottere, from late Old English pottere (“potter”), equivalent to pot +‎ -er, influenced by Old French potier (“potter”). More at pot. Displaced Old English crocwyrhta (literally “pot worker”).

entries.meaning: One who makes pots and other ceramic wares.
examples: shoemakers, weavers, potters, bronzeworkers who produced and purveyed the articles necessary for daily life.

entries.meaning: One who places flowers or other plants inside their pots.
One who pots meats or other eatables.
One who hawks crockery or earthenware.
examples: the convivial society of gipsies, tinkers, potters, strolling players, &c.

entries.meaning: The red-bellied terrapin, Pseudemys rubriventris (species of turtle).

description: Frequentative of pote, equivalent to pote +‎ -er. Cognate with Dutch poteren, peuteren (“to poke, pry, search”).

verbs.description: potter (third-person singular simple present potters, present participle pottering, simple past and past participle pottered)

entries.meaning: (Britain) To act in a vague or unmotivated way; to fuss about with unimportant things.
(Britain) To move slowly or aimlessly. (Often potter about, potter around.)
